item.title: Rockstar hit with legal claims by IWGB over firing of unionizing workers
item.content:encoded:
Image via Rockstar Games/Take-Two Interactive.

British labor union Independent Workers of Great Britain (IWGB) is escalating its legal fight with Grand Theft Auto VI developer Rockstar over the firing of over 30 union members on November 2, 2025. It has now issued formal legal claims against Rockstar for its actions, bringing the dispute before the British courts.

In an announcement, the union stated that it repeatedly sought meetings with Rockstar to resolve the conflict through negotiation, only to be stonewalled by the studio. Describing the termination as "unacceptable and unlawful," the union said it is issuing these claims on behalf of the affected workers. 

"Our members allege that Rockstar’s conduct constitutes trade union victimization and blacklisting," said the IWGB legal team. This filing comes days after Rockstar announced Grand Theft Auto VI will be delayed until November 2026.

Union president Alex Marshall declared that Rockstar has engaged in "plain and simple union busting," and that the organization would mount a full legal events. "Employers like Rockstar would do well to understand that private spaces such as trade union Discord servers have protections, and that their company’s contractual clauses do not supersede UK law."

Marshall was referring to Rockstar's claim that it fired the unionizing workers for "gross misconduct," specifically the leaking of trade secrets. Last week the union informed Game Developer that union members had been speaking with organizers in a private Discord server, where they never discussed Rockstar products or plans.

Related:Sony unveils Japanese-language-only PlayStation 5 at $350

A few days ago, fired Rockstar employee "Bran" told YouTube outlet People Make Games that the union was "very close" to reaching the number of members for statutory recognition under UK law. She also noted that new union recognition procedures were set to be implemented in 2026 that would have made the process "easier" for organizing employees.

Game Developer has reached out to Rockstar parent company Take-Two Interactive for comment, and will update this story when the company responds.

item.title: Sony unveils Japanese-language-only PlayStation 5 at $350
item.content:encoded:
Diego Argüello, Contributing Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

November 12, 2025

1 Min Read

Newsbrief: Sony has announced a Japanese-language-only PlayStation 5 with a suggested retail price of 55,000 yen, which equals to roughly $350.

Announced during the State of Play Japan held on November 11, the company called the announcement "something very special for the Japanese market." The model, which is the Digital Edition of the console, doesn't have any other standout feature. The box, however, does include "Console Language: Japanese Only" underneath the name.

The console is launching on November 21 of this year. It proposes a considerable discount compared to the regular models, especially after the price increase in the United States back in August. With the latter, each console saw a $50 price hike. The Digital Edition, for example, jumped from $449.99 to $499.99, while the PlayStation 5 Pro went from $699.99 to $749.00.

As noted in Sony's fiscal report for the second quarter ended September 30, 2025, the PlayStation 5 sold 3.5 million units during Q2, reaching 84.2 million lifetime sales.
